scenario_text: Lately, I've been feeling really conflicted about using Snapchat. Whenever I scroll through my feed, I often come across images of half-naked girls or promotions for OnlyFans accounts. The hardest part is that it keeps happening, and it feels like there's no escape from it.

Lately, I've been noticing a pattern in my social media habits that's been bothering me. This isn't just something that happens to me; it's a common issue that many people face, even if they don't consider themselves addicted to social media. When I catch myself in this cycle, I usually try to close the app and focus on something else, but it's tough not to get drawn back in. The worst part of this experience is the guilt I feel afterward. I can't help but think about all the productive things I could have done instead of wasting time on my phone. It's a frustrating habit that I'm trying to break.

When I was between 14 and 16, I was part of this online community where I had a bad habit of saying really outrageous stuff just to shock people. I didn't really care about boundaries, and the forum wasn't well-moderated, which kind of enabled my behavior. There were people of all ages there, and honestly, the adults weren't acting responsibly either. This behavior took over my life for a while, and it's something I still think about a lot. At first, I was angry and thought my comments were just weird jokes, but looking back now as an adult, I realize it was much more serious. Now, whenever I meet new people, I'm super careful about what I say and always check in to make sure I'm not making anyone uncomfortable. The worst part is that this part of my life will always be there, affecting not just me but others too. I thought people had mostly forgotten about it, but just a month ago, I saw someone from back then talking about me on another site. They even lied about what I did, which is confusing because the truth was actually worse than the lie. It's a tough lesson, but I've learned to be more considerate and respectful.

Recently, I came across a post on social media that really opened my eyes to how quickly things can get negative online. The guy was just trying to show how he was getting his dogs used to being in a crate for practical reasons. But then, I noticed the comments section was blowing up with people accusing him of being cruel and mistreating his dogs. The original poster tried to explain himself and respond to some of the hate, but it didn't seem to matter; people had already made up their minds about him. I felt really sorry for the guy and was shocked at how quickly people online got angry over something that seemed so innocent. To show my support, I disliked some of the worst hate comments. The worst part of it all was seeing how much negativity this seemingly innocent post and poster had to endure for no good reason.

Social media can be a wild place, especially with all the shallow and over-generalized statements people post just to get a reaction. Recently, I came across a tweet that really got under my skin: 'Don't marry a man who expects you to provide 50/50 and go to work.' This wasn't the first time this person had posted something like this; just last week, they had another tweet blow up with thousands of likes and retweets from big accounts. I guess they thought they could replicate that success, but this time it just came off as weird and out of touch. I couldn't stay silent, so I decided to voice my thoughts without revealing who I was. The whole situation was ridiculous to me. In today's world, it's almost impossible for a household to survive on a single income, especially with multiple people. Advice like this, if taken seriously, could ruin many healthy relationships where both partners are willing to make sacrifices for each other. It's just not realistic.

scenario_text: Starting university was a huge deal for me, especially since I didn't know anyone there. I really wanted to put myself out there and make friends, so I watched tons of YouTube tutorials and guides on how to socialize. I thought I was preparing myself, but I didn't realize that watching videos isn't the same as actually making an effort to talk to people. When I finally tried to socialize, it felt super uncomfortable, so I just went back to watching more videos. I ended up spending my entire first year alone, feeling like I was being productive but actually just isolating myself more. It made me feel really isolated and unhappy because I kept seeing other people on YouTube who made it look so easy, and I couldn't understand why I couldn't do the same. The worst part is that this feeling still affects me, and I haven't been able to fix it yet.

The worst part was feeling like I didn't belong anywhere. Seeing people say such horrible things about people who look like me made me question if I was even safe here. It was really hard to focus on my studies or anything else because I felt so isolated and unsure of who I could talk to about how I was feeling.

As an artist, I've been struggling with my presence on social media, especially Instagram. It's so easy to get caught up in comparing myself to other creatives who seem to be constantly producing amazing work. I found myself falling into the trap of judging my own worth based on these digital snapshots of other people's lives. Without knowing anything about their personal struggles or setbacks, I started to feel like I wasn't good enough. This constant comparison made me feel useless and like I wasn't living up to my potential as an artist. I began to doubt my abilities and felt like I wasn't creating enough, and when I did create, I was overly critical of my work. This led me into a creative slump where I stopped producing art altogether because I didn't like anything I made and kept beating myself up over it. The worst part was that it made me question my entire identity and whether I had chosen the right path by pursuing an art degree. It was a tough period, but I'm trying to remind myself that social media doesn't show the full picture of anyone's life.

scenario_text: Recently, I had a really tough experience with social media that left me feeling pretty shaken. An acquaintance of mine posted a video of me without my knowledge or consent. The video was an inside joke within my friend group, something that only we would understand and find funny. Unfortunately, when it was shared online, people outside our circle saw it and didn't get the context. Instead, they found it crude and started criticizing me. This whole situation made me feel incredibly embarrassed and upset. It felt like a violation of my privacy, knowing that something meant for close friends was now out there for strangers to see. I was especially worried about other acquaintances seeing the video and forming a negative opinion of me based on it. When I confronted the acquaintance who posted it, I was upset but tried to be clear and direct about why it was wrong to share the video without my consent. The worst part was knowing that people who don't really know me might now have this crude and unfavorable impression of who I am. It was a really tough lesson about the importance of consent and privacy in the digital age.
